title: How many people will have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19 in the US as of 30 April 2021, according to the CDC?
preds:
This is called flip-flopping at the eleventh hour... to be fair @CJH tried to warn us about this a few days ago (Thank you!). 
So as the time of reckoning drew near, I decided to dig into the trends_in_number_of_covid19_vaccinations_in_the_us.csv. What do I find? Some decent evidence of significant retroactive adjustments. For example, see the below cumulative figures

2021-04-26	98359857			
2021-04-27	99456876			
2021-04-28	99668948			
2021-04-29	99668948 Obviously, it's not true that there were zero vaccinations today, also it's most likely not true there were only ~ 0.23m vaccinations on Apr 28 (99.67m - 99.46m). So what's probably the case is that Apr 27's final figure is close to 99.46m. That means there are three more days and the average daily rate ~ 1.5m +. This should significantly change the likelihood of crossing 105. To be conservative, I think, I am going to go roughly 45:55.

As of April 29th, the CDC reports that 99,668,948 people have been fully vaccinated. With only one day left, it is unlikely that the number of fully vaccinated individuals will surpass 105 million. Even at its peak only 2.5 million people were reported fully vaccinated in a day and there has been a recent downward trend in the number of people becoming fully vaccinated every day.

Update 4/29: 99.7M today. 98.0M yesterday. 1.7M added. ~2.75M total doses reported today; 62% of total reported added to fully vaccinated. J&J may be having an effect. 
Effectively ~4 more reporting days to go; need to add ~3 back reporting days. Last week, added 1.5M/day average to the total number of people fully vaccinated. Project an average of 2.75M doses reported/day for the next 4 days and adding ~1.7M/day to the total number of people fully vaccinated. Then total should be approx. 99.7M (today's value) + 4 * 1.7M (4 more days) = 106.5M. Even if 1.5M/day average added for the next 4 days, total = 99.7M + 1.5M * 4 = 105.7M.
From another angle: project ~14.5M more doses administered by April 30 than are shown now, leading to a weekly average of ~2.75M/day, continuing the decline. 14.5M * 0.6 (may be an underestimate) = 8.7M more people could be added to the number of people fully vaccinated. Then total = 99.7M + 8.7M = 108.4M.
So final total should be approx. 106M to 108M.
Settling for 105m+. Expecting 105.x als final number.
The vaccination rate is clearly slowing down.  Going to be close, but looks likely to fall short of 105 million.

It dipped to a daily rate of 1.4 million but I think it's likely to stay there or recover a bit to 1.6, dose 2 trend will be close to the dose 1 trend from 21 to 28 days ago. Around 95 million doses a week ago plus 1.4 million a day would be around 107, and usually the numbers continue to get revised up a bit as time passes so I think 110 million could be reached, but 115 still seems pretty unlikely, but I'm giving it 10% because J&J unpaused and it seems plausible it could add a few million shots in the last week of April.
Trend rate seems to be slowing and having a hard time seeing it move past 105 now unless the last few days have been substantially underreported

Update 4/28: 98.0M. Effectively 5 more reporting days to go; need to add 3 back reporting days.
4/21: 87.6M. 10.4M people added in the past week; 1.49M/day. 
98.0M + 1.49M * 5 = 105.45M.
To look at it from another angle, ~2.25M doses reported today, and ~1.3M people were added to this total, or ~58% of today's reported vaccines being administered. If an average of ~2.75M vaccines/day are reported for the coming 5 days, that would add ~2.75M * 5 * 0.58 = 8.0M to today's total, or 98.0M + 8.0M = 106.0M (pretty close to 105.45M).
On the one hand, vaccination rates are going down. On the other hand, the J&J vaccine is now being used a bit, and the rest are people who got a first dose 3 weeks ago. This forecast is right on the line, but I think the higher bin is looking more likely after all.
It is probably going to be just over 105m, in the end
CDC data shows ~ 98m. 7m in 3 (or 4) days has become more unlikely. Adjusted down by 5%.
wish i had trusted my reading of the numbers more on my last forecast!

The fully vaccinated rate is slowing for a number of reason that I have posted about before.  It looks like the number is going to be right below 105 million.  I am moving to a 50/50 forecast for now, which I really do not like doing, but it accounts for both the possibility that current trends continues over the last four days and revise in ordering or a unforeseen surge in vaccination.
Already 96 million. Small chance of adding 9 million given apparently falling daily rate and reports of people skipping second doses.
105m more likely, still. But closer than expected.
J&J's temp pause probably taking its toll- the pace hasn't picked up after the 'pause' been lifted. 95-105 seems likely now.

There are currently 95.8M individuals that are fully vaccinated in the US. About 1.5M people are added to this number each day.  With 4 days remaining, it is incredibly likely that the number of individuals will stay below 105M.

The rolling weekly numbers have steadily drifted downwards, currently ~ 10.5 million. Which translates to about 1.5 m per day. Whether we think there are 4 days left or 5 days remaining, it's hard to reach 105 AT THIS RATE. And yet, there is still a good chance of getting to 105, because, we might see a couple of 2 million days. Keeping a close eye on this one!
4/26: 95.9M. Effectively 6 more reporting days to go. Too close to call with J&J also now in the mix. If 1M J&J vaccines are given this week, that could tip the forecast into the 105M to 115M bin.

Mean estimate is 105.77M, just over the bin boundary.  As pointed out by @CJH, if J&J vaccines are administered this week it could boost the numbers a bit.  So I'll overweight 105-115M vis-à-vis the crowd.

Going to 95% for 105m+ after seeing CDC data of today:
95.9m for April 25. This will be corrected to roughly 99m as reportings come in for that day. In order to reach 105m, 105-99 =6m are necessary for the last 5 days which is 1.2m/d. 7 day average has never gone below 1.2m in April, and J&J is being delivered again.
(Only reason I am not going 100% for 105m+ is that I already had a glass of wine with dinner and want to check again tomorrow if this was the reason for my confidence.)
9 million people got their first dose 3 weeks ago, so we can expect 9 million or less to get their second dose this week.

Updating forecast to reduce the 85M to 95M probability to 0%.  Based on data the 95M mark will be past today or tomorrow.  If trends continue, it would appear that number will be between 105M and 107M.  However, there are a number of reports of vaccination saturation.  Those that really wanted to get vaccinated have been vaccinated or about to do so.  The opening up of vaccination for 16 and up may offset this trend.  Vaccinations in rural areas appears to have dropped off, which is not surprising since the rural areas are the most vaccine skeptic.  Reallocation of vaccines in rural areas to urban areas is politically risky, but could support a continued positive trend of vaccinations.  We are reaching a point where it appears that supply is outstripping demand, as well as a need to reallocate how the supply of vaccines are distributed.

In addition to recent trends:
Millions Are Skipping Their Second Doses of Covid Vaccines
https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/25/business/covid-vaccines-second-doses.html

It looks like it could be close, since the CDC's website is still updating, but right now it does appear that the trend of the number of people who are fully vaccinated has slowed, suggesting the total may not be higher than 105,000,000.
Going down to 75% for 105m+....also this one's pretty suspenseful.

4/17: 84.3M
4/25: 94.8M
10.5M people added in the past week. Add 7 more days at this rate (inc. 2 for back reporting) => 94.8M + 10.5M = 105.3M. Vaccinations seem to be falling a bit, too. Too close to call yet.

88.4m with a 7 day rolling ave of 1.37m and declining as of 19 Apr. News reports suggest that people are missing their second doses [1] so I expect the rate to continue declining. 11 days left to report data. I think the consensus is slightly overconfident, though J&J re-approval may lead to some acceleration. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2021/04/25/business/covid-vaccines-second-doses.html
88.4M as of Apr 19. Needs 1.5M per day to get to 105M, but current 7 day moving average is 1.37M
I don't see the increase in the vaccination rate even after the pause on J&J being lifted. This suggests people may be hesitant in taking J&J. Will check back in a couple of days.

91.2M as of Apr.23, +~1.6/day + J&J, 8 days, everyone is eligible but no significant daily increase. 105 is the bubble, probably going to fall short now. Pretty disappointed its not higher, but it is what it is. Could be surprised but not banking on it.

Already over 90MM, and gaining 1-3/day. More vaccine a positive force and growing vaccine resistance a negative force. Some of the resistance is “partisan”, a small amount in generic antivax, and some is the hope that the risk is dropping so why bother with the hassle.

4/17: 82.5M
4/23: 91.2M
(91.2M - 82.5M) / 6 = 1.45M
91.2M + 1.45M * 9 days (inc. 2 for back reporting) = 104.25M
Surprising how much and how quickly vaccine administration is slowing down.
Reintroduction of J&J should hasten things up again

91.2m.  13.8m to 105m, 6 days to go which is 2.3m per day.  Take off 2m for reporting lag and still need 1.9m. Current rate at 1.4m and still dropping. Will get to 95m, but no way now to 105m as average has never gone over 1.8m

There appears to be a slight drop over the week in the number of people getting their second shot of the COVID vaccine.  This could also be the loss of the J&J vaccine finally being baked into the numbers, despite its small proportion of the overall share.  It appears that the number is going to be right around the 105 million mark.  Still accounting for an foreseen problem over the weekend that disrupts vaccination rates and numbers fall short.
Adjusting forecast due to passage of time and progress

Update. I think we are hitting vaccine hesitancy, or at least a group of people who feel a less urgent need to get vaccinated. Doses reported per day now are lower than a couple weeks ago. I think a higher bracket is looking increasingly unlikely.
4/22: 89.2M
4/17: 82.5M
From 4/10 to 4/17: 2.0M added/day.
From 4/17 to 4/21: 1.7M added/day. Will probably be a bit higher for the week, as 3 out of the past 4 reporting days were low reporting days.
So, suppose ~2M/day added from 4/17. Add 15 days (to include back reporting): 82.5M + 15 days * ~2M/day = 112.5M.
To reach 115M, would need to add an average of ~2.17M/day. That doesn't seem likely at this point, but it's possible.
To hit 105M, would need to add an average of ~1.5M/day. That doesn't seem likely, either.

Update 4/21: To date, 87.6M people have been fully vaccinated.
4/10: 68.2M
4/17: 82.5M
4/21: 87.6M
From 4/10 to 4/17: 2.0M added/day.
From 4/17 to 4/21: 1.3M added/day. But the past 3 days are the lowest reporting days of the week. So perhaps the week will end up with ~2M added/day average.
With a linear forecast: 82.5M + 2M/day * 15.5 days (for delayed reporting) = 113.5M.
The question is, will vaccine administration rates continue to go up?
Suppose 2 days for reporting lag, for 15 days after 4/17. To get to 115M, would need to have 32.5M doses/15 days = 2.17M doses/day average. So if vaccine administration continues to go up, then the week of 4/17 should see ~2.1M doses/day added, and the following week ~2.2M doses/day added. This would put us right on the cusp between bins. The 95M to 105M bin, which seems to be growing in popularity right now, is almost impossible, by the way. We are already at 87.6M. The past 3 days were low reporting days of the week; the next few days will be substantially higher. But if we add only 2M people/day * 9 remaining days of the forecast, then we're already at 105.6M. But we'll need to add a coupe more days of back reporting after the end of the month; that would put us at 110M. And that's not even making up for the past few low reporting days.

It appears that the US will be right around 106 million fully vaccinated Americans by the end of next week.  It is likely to be very close between the two tiers around 105 million.  Still accounting for possible slow downs in the supply chain and delivery process for unforeseen reasons as well as the possibility of approaching the saturation point of those eager to be vaccinated.

https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/public-health/states-ranked-by-percentage-of-population-vaccinated-march-15.html Maine has the highest percentage of its population fully vaccinated against COVID-19, according to the CDC's COVID-19 vaccine distribution and administration data tracker. The CDC's data tracker compiles data from healthcare facilities and public health authorities. It updates daily to report the total number of people in each state who have been fully vaccinated against COVID-19. The numbers reported by the CDC may vary from the numbers published on individual states' public health websites, as there may be reporting lags between the states and the CDC.  As of 6 a.m. EDT April 20, a total of 86,223,506 Americans had been fully vaccinated, or 26 percent of the country's population, according to the CDC's data.
Expanding vaccination pool to people who want a jab, but don't need it is likely to slow down 2nd jabs and stagnate first jab rates over the next couple weeks.
The second doses are raising less than the first with maximum 2 millions of doses each day. Today there are more than 85 millions people vaccinated two times.

85.3m.  19.7m to 105m, 9 days to go which is 2.1m per day.  Take off 2m for reporting lag and still need 1.9m. Current rate at 1.6m and dropping.  2nd shots will not drop off as much as 1st doses as they will focus on giving the 2nd does in a timely manner I believe and 1st doses can be more easily delayed.
But with this weeks drop off it has dramatically increased the required daily numbers needed to reach each threshold Revising down a band

The fly in the ointment is obviously the pause on J&J vaccine, so when I separately modeled the time-series for the 2nd dose, there is a non-trivial chance of ending up below 105 million. I expect a base line of 9 million/week rate, but I also think we should expect an  increase in the capacity (of the delivery system) to meet the increased demand after April 15.  I might end up revising, but there is still a good chance that we cross 105 million by April 30.
Tweaking forecast, progress seems to be leading towards 105M or more.

Leaning towards a smaller increase in fully vaccinated individuals because of the stop on J&J; while the other vaccines require 2 doses to count as fully vaccinated, CDC was counting J&J towards fully vaxx'd population with 1 dose. Since J&J is off the table for now, plus with a possible increase in vaccine hesitancy due to 1. messaging around J&J and 2. many very-pro vaccine people already reciving vaccinations, I think that this number will skew lower over the next few weeks.

84.2m with 11 days to go.
Average 1.7m gives 102.9m. But need to add a few m to account for reporting delay.   Will be over 105m if the average does not drop off.  Been a dip the past few days.  If this is the effect of J&J then as expect to drop a bit more.  As 1.7m per day is close to 105m have give some probability to less than that range. https://eu.usatoday.com/in-depth/graphics/2021/04/17/how-johnson-johnson-pause-due-blood-clots-could-slow-vaccines/7243236002/
Potential to drop by 20pc.  But I’m assuming that 2nd doses are the same as 1st dose and not many 2nd dose people will have had the J&J vaccine as it was started lasted, so going for less of a dip than 20pc.
Keep monitoring.

78M as of Apr 12. At the most recent rate of 1.7M per day, we'd get 78+1.7*18 = 108.6M. My median is a bit below this due to J&J stoppage, something like 78+1.55*18=105.9M.
It seems very unlikely that it falls outside the 95-115M range, and I think it's slightly more likely than not to end up above 105M, so my unadjusted view is ~45/55. I'll adjust to 38/62 based on others' forecasts.

After looking at todays numbers and reading @belikewater 's comment, I changed my forecast 
105m+ : 100% > 80% 
115m+:       0% > 20%

Update 4/17: Looking MUCH higher, as we appear to be increasingly hitting a saturation of vaccine demand.
In the past week, 82.5M - 68.2M = 14.3M people added who are fully vaccinated. More than 2 weeks left in forecast period (i.e., including reporting delays) => more than 28M more people will be added. 82.5M + 28.6M = 111.1M! This should be a lower limit.
What's going on? How were so many fully vaccinated people added last week? Just over 3M/day vaccines given (average) => ~3M*7=~21M doses administered; that means 2/3 * the doses administered currently go to fully vaccinated people. That's much higher than before; the long term average has been ~39%. To me, that says that we're approaching a saturation of vaccine demand, as an increasing fraction of doses are second doses. 
So: ~8.8M more doses for this week + 2 weeks at ~3.25M/day and ~3.4M/day = 55.4M more doses administered. So, around, say, 54M to 58M more doses administered by April 30.
(2/3) * 55.4M = ~36.9M more fully vaccinated people.
82.5M fully vaccinated to date + 36.9M more = 119.4M!
Average increasing fast as expected.  Adding a little for the 5 day lag in reporting. See previous comment

The current number of fully vaccinated Americans is 80.6M.  There are 3M vaccines given each day.  Assuming each person receives 2 doses to be fully vaccinated. 80.6M * (1.5M*14 days) = 101.6M (high end assuming the 3M are used to fully vaccinate individuals) 
80.6M * (1M*14 days) = 94.6M (low end with vaccines being spread in distribution)

76m today. 
15 days to go.  Current average about 1.5m per day getting to full dose = 22.5 more = 98.5m More 2nd doses likely in next few weeks to keep up with increase in 1st doses 6 -12 weeks ago.  Could increase strongly as this is when 1st dose rates increases fast.  This can be seen in how the 7 day rolling average is increasing
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccination-trends
In next few days the rolling average is likely to be over 1.8m per day, but that’s still not quite high enough to get to 105m.
Threshold for 95m = 19m = 1.27m per day
Threshold for 105m = 29m = 1.93m per day
Threshold for 115m = 39m = 2.6m per day
Shifting down due to the J&J pause.
Suspension of J&J vaccine would likely take a while to resolve, and significantly reduces the probability of exceeding ~108 million.

74M fully vaccinated as of Apr. 12. Assuming average 25 days between doses anyone in the last 7 days won't be eligible to be fully vaccinated in timeframe. ~38M will be eligible for 2nd dose before Apr.30. Likely to be stragglers from that group, but there are already some so should have minimal effect on total.  J&J says they're on track for 24M deliveries in April although there is some skepticism on that number (only 1.5M expected this week, down from 11 last, increased production 'could happen by end of month'). So theoretically ~135M could be fully vaccinated if all goes to current plans and everyone sticks to schedule. Current number is increasing by ~1.7M/day meaning an additional 31M if trend continues, but trend has been increasing. So lets say half of J&J's expected deliveries are fulfilled and number of second doses is between 31 and 38M, that makes ~117-124M, probably to the lower end https://www.wsj.com/articles/j-j-covid-19-vaccine-deliveries-to-drop-significantly-next-week-11617970201

Hedging toward the crowd a bit and being a little less optimistic in J&J doses. 105+ million full doses just based on Moderna and Pfizer's 21-28 day second dose window counting from April 1, plus maybe 10 to 20 million J&J puts me at 115-125. Going with a little larger tail on the right because I think there's a good chance J&J gets their issues sorted out this month and issues a good number of doses. Also I will get counted in dose 2 statistics later this month so I'm pretty excited about that.
It is expected that despite wide availability of vaccinations once economy and business open up most people will start forgetting about getting a second dose.

68m today. 
20 days to go.  Current average about 1.3m per day getting to full dose = 26m more = 94m More 2nd doses likely in next few weeks to keep up with increase in 1st doses 6 -12 weeks ago.  Could increase strongly as this is when 1st dose rates increases fast. Threshold for 95m = 27m = 1.35m per day
Threshold for 105m = 37m = 1.85m per day
Threshold for 115m = 47m = 2.35m per day
Update. Looks really likely to me that the number will be between 96M and 99M, continuing current trends.

Estimate about ~78.0M (or as low as ~75.5M) more vaccinations administered between now and April 30. Total vaccinations administered * 0.38 = number of people fully vaccinated. 0.38 = (number of people fully vaccinated) / (number of vaccine doses administered); this number has been pretty constant. To date, 68.2M fully vaccinated. By April 30, then total should be approximately between 68.2M + 75.5M * 0.38 = 96.9M and 68.2M + 78.0M * 0.38 = 97.9M. This is well under the number of people who are expected to take 2 doses (i.e., demand should remain high) and is based on current vaccination trends continuing.
~65 million as of today. Vaccines are going to start becoming available to all adults very soon.
This is an update for my previous forecast

This is going to be the number of people receiving 1 out of 2 doses plus the number of Johnson and Johnson doses. Per the CDC definitions, both the one dose and fully vaccinated categories count the J&J shot. So subtracting them should still give the correct total of those who have gotten one dose and will get a second over the coming month (21 days for Pfizer, 28 days for Moderna). As of April 1 there were 105.4 million single dose vaccinations and 44.8 full vaccinations, a difference of 60.6 million. So for Pfizer and Moderna I think that will be the ballpark increase in full vaccinations (plus a few million more because Pfizer's lag is only 21 days). So that would be about 44.8 + 60 = 105 million full vaccinations. That's not counting additional J&J shots. According to the company, despite the recent setbacks with spoiled doses they still intend to deliver 100 million doses by the end of May. https://www.jnj.com/johnson-johnson-statement-on-u-s-covid-19-vaccine-manufacturing-updated I'd guess this month between the already delivered doses of J&J and the ones that will be delivered this month J&J could be an additional 20 to 40 million doses. So I'm guessing a grand total of 125 million to 145 million second doses by the end of the month. But I'm leaving a large tail on the lower side in case J&J has issues or more manufacturing or safety issues are discovered with it.

Based on current CDC data, average vaccine rate growth daily is around 500,000-1,000,000
Current people fully Vaccinated: 64,422,621 (as of April 7)
Current vaccination rate per day (fully vaccinated): Around 1,300,000
Estimated people fully vaccinated at end of April: between 99,000,000-110,000,000
63m as of 7 April, 1.2m new "fully vaccinated" per day on a 7-day average. At that pace, 90.6m will be fully vaccinated by EOM.

Everyone with at least 1 dose right now should be fully vaccinated by end May. This sets a lower bound of 108 million. In addition, over 12 million J&J doses have been delivered to the government, while only over 4 million have been administered. If all those vaccines get administered before end-of-month, which I believe is possible, the expected value should be 120 million. I believe exceeding 125 million is also quite likely, as ~1.6 million people are getting vaccinated each day, which means the current number of people with at least one dose should be closer to 113 million. In addition, there is the possibility of J&J deliveries ramping up, which would significantly increase the numbers beyond the estimation presented here. However, there is also a chance of the above being an overestimation, because the moderna vaccine requires 28 days between doses, instead of 21, and the time between doses for both pfizer and moderna vaccines can be stretched to 42 days according to the CDC.
